abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the project is
            satisfactory, and sustainability is likely . The key lessons
            convey that the parastatal framework within which most
            railway systems have been operating, has proven inadequate
            for the delivery of effective transport services,
            particularly under economic liberalization scenarios, and
            the consequent inter-modal competition; thus, a sharp
            decline in railway traffic - both freight, and passenger -
            has been experienced. In addition, the efforts to reform the
            organizational structure of railways within a parastatal
            framework, bares no significant impact, due to excessive
            employment, lack of incentives, and inadequate
            accountability. It becomes clear, that if railway operations
            are to succeed, an adequate framework for reform needs to be
            implemented. Furthermore, private participation in
            railways' operation, and management through
            concessions, has apparently renewed railway transportation
            modes; even in Zimbabwe, the concession for a new link, led
            to substantial increases in the railroad freight traffic.
            Therefore, since railway privatization appears to be
            unavoidable, the delay for private participation, will prove
            costly, aggravated in Sub-Saharan Africa by the financial
            pressures the governments are facing. Finally, the
            successful restructuring, and privatization of railways is
            liable to an urgent staff redundancy program.

abstracts.cdata!:
The proposed project provides assistance
            to the National Railways of Zimbabwe (NRZ) to implement a
            restructuring program with four principal components: (a)
            organization restructuring; (b) operations improvement
            program; (c) assets restructuring; and (d) financial
            restructuring.  The project consists of 1) technical
            assistance to support a management and supervisory
            development program and introduce improved working systems,
            2) training and secondment of staff to overseas rrailways,
            3) funding of a manpower study and studies on NRZ's
            management information systems and locomotive maintenance
            practices, 4) software and technical assistance for
            accounting, yard information and locomotives monitoring
            systems, 5) procurement of new and repowering of some
            existing locomotives, 6) replacement of over-aged or
            obsolete rail and off-rail service vehicles, workshop plant
            and equipment and signalling and telecommunications
            equipment; and 7) minor extension of the electrified track structure.
